description.narrative:
Oxfam Novib and its partners, Bedari and Indus Resource Center (IRC), will implement the MTBA programme in four Union Councils (UC), namely Larkana and Shikarpur in Northern Sindh and Muzaffargarh and Lodhran in South Punjab. Over the 5 years of implementation, the programme will target a total of 80 villages. Review of secondary literature indicates that the issue of child marriage is multilayered, spanning socio-cultural, religious, economic and legal dimensions. Any effective measures to address it, therefore, need to be multi-pronged confronting these various dimensions. Moreover, social norms and values, including honour and tradition, are major factors that play a role in early marriage. Therefore, interventions need to be comprehensive, with multiple entry-points, and, moreover, be firmly rooted with the local context. It is for this reason that the MTBA in Pakistan emphasises creating awareness and promoting harmful norms change whilst contributing to a more egalitarian and safe environment for adolescent girls. The MTBA will sensitise and build the capacity of youth to claim their rights and to protect themselves from child marriage.
The project is aimed ataddressing the issue of child marriages through multi-pronged strategies. Its planned outcomes are: Outcome 1: Young people are better informed about SRHR, including adverse effects of child marriage and empowered to voice their needs and rights Outcome 2: Increased access to formal education for girls at risk of and affected by child marriage Outcome 3: Increased access to economic opportunities for girls at risk of and affected by child marriage, and their families Outcome 4: Increased access to child protection systems for girls at risk of and affected by child marriage Outcome 5: Increased utilization of SRHR services that are responsive to the needs of young people, particular girls at risk of-, and affected by child marriage Outcome 6: Increased engagement and collective social action against child marriage and in support of ASRHR Outcome 7: Supportive rights-based legal and policy environment against child marriage

participating-org.narrative:
Indus Resource Centre has been working in the Sindh province of Pakistan for over a decade. It has grown fast, from being a one person NGO supported by like minded individuals, and a few one room schools for girls in rural Sindh, to a midsized organization with over 800 staff, several programme and project offices and work which addresses the more basic issues of livelihoods and people empowerment along with education for the poor and deprived.
It was founded on the assumption that marginalised communities have unexplored potential and if their capacity is built and they are supported in self-organisation they can improve their individual and collective lives. IRC started its field operations in Khairpur and Dadu districts in the year 2000. From the outset, partnerships with selected CBOs/NGOs were developed and efforts were made to enhance managerial and technical capacities of individuals and institutions. Education emerged as the most important programme followed by economic initiatives. Dialogueswith partners identified these thematicareas but as the community development process moved ahead other themes such as rural physical infrastructure and disaster responsewere added. Most of the partner CBOs became implementation partners in schools, micro-credit, rural physical infrastructure and sustainable livelihood programs. Trainings were organized to build their institutional capacities and project implementation capacities so that they could become effective implementers.
Partnership meetingsheld fairly regularly and partners identified the issues that became subjects of project development. Several donors supported projects under these themes and efforts were made to establish and intensify linkages between various projects and programs. IRC#s outreach is in 9 districts of Sindh through long-term programs and projects: Khairpur, Sukkur, Shikarpur, Kashmore, Ghotki, Kambar-Shahdadkot, Dadu, Karachi and Jamshoro.
Staff of IRC number 800+ in total, 500 being teachers, and the rest as program and project staff including the non-teaching staff in schools. An eleven-member Board consisting of four founding members and two development professionals from the project area governs IRC. The members have expertise in education, social development,engineering, architecture, health, finance, media relations, and other related fields. The Board meets at least twice a year and takes the important decisions regarding policies and programs.
The Executive Director heads the organisation and is responsible for achieving overall objectives and ensuring adherence to the Code of Conduct of IRC. She facilitates and guides the processes of planning and monitoring, framing of policies and systems, recruitment of staff, assigning responsibilities, and exercising supervision and disciplinary control. She is responsible for fund raising and liaising with senior government officials and donor agencies and reports to the Board of Director. Below her are Regional Coordinators for Khairpur and Dadu whoare assistedby District Coordinators and other project staff. The four main program areas # Governance, Democracy and Human Rights;Education and Literacy; Sustainable Livelihoods and Disaster Risk Management - are led by program heads who provide thematic supporttorelated projects.
